intro: You’ve matched with the cutie of your dreams on Bumble or Tinder—now all that’s left to do is slide into their DMs! But how do you strike up a convo in a way that’s fresh and original, and how do you keep the conversation going? To help you make a positive and lasting first impression, we’ve assembled expert tips for breaking the ice on a dating app, plus over 50 customizable scripting ideas to help get you started. Get ready to meet your soulmate!

points.name: Ask them about something they put in their profile.

steps.title: Acknowledging their profile will show you’re invested in them.
steps.subtitle: In the modern age, we’re all just swiping and swiping and swiping through profiles, so take the time to really look at what someone’s written in their bio—mean a lot. Plus, studies show people love to talk about themselves if given the chance!  by pointing out something specific you noticed in their profile and asking them more about it.
sub-points: We asked  how they initiate conversations with people online, and  said they

steps.title: "Would You Rather” is a great way to learn more about their personality.
steps.subtitle: It’s not only a fun, lighthearted game; it really gives you insight into the way someone thinks (and gives them insight about you too!). Next time you match with a hot single, make a lasting impression by

steps.title: Open questions give them the chance to say whatever they want.
steps.subtitle: This will help you learn more about them—and it’ll take some pressure off of  to be a great conversationalist!  and follow up with prompts that , like “Tell me more about that!” It's a great way to get someone to open up and feel more comfortable.
sub-points: Stay on topic rather than jumping from new question to new question, or else it could come off like an interrogation. () And, talk about yourself now and again!

steps.title: Make sure you're looking for the same thing from the get-go.
steps.subtitle: There’s no harm in being proactive with your icebreaker! Ask what they’re looking for in a relationship ( they’re looking for a relationship) to help you determine if it’s worth pursuing a first date with them. Are they looking for something long-term? A summer fling? Getting right to the point can save you both some time, but be sure to say “hello” first to avoid coming across too brusque!

points.name: Talk about what you’re looking for in a relationship.

steps.title: Let them know what your intentions are off the bat.
steps.subtitle: If you're hesitant to ask them what they’re looking for, just ! Are you looking for a serious relationship, are you here for just a casual fling, or are you just along for the ride?

steps.title: Get up close and personal to learn who they really are.
steps.subtitle: Lots of people appreciate small talk as an opportunity to get comfortable with one another before getting into a more serious topic. But asking a deep question right off the bat can help you  sooner. Plus, their willingness to engage in a personal conversation with a stranger can give you a sense of how open their personality is.
sub-points: That’s not to say it’s a red flag if they choose not to get too deep with a stranger—they may not feel comfortable talking about certain deep subjects, or they may just be shy.

steps.title: Kick it old-school: plan a first date and get to know them IRL.
steps.subtitle: Skip over the virtual get-to-know-yous and jump ahead to the  portion of the chat. You can get to know each other in person over your favorite pizza or a game of darts. (Just make sure you meet in a public place and tell your friends where you’re going!) Even if it turns out not to be a match made in heaven, who knows? You may still have a great time. And if not, you’ve got a good story to share on a future first date.
sub-points: "Let's get coffee" might be your go-to first date, but if you don't know someone well (or at all), it can be a little awkward just sitting there. Try to make your first date somewhat activity-based, like mini-golfing or a walk in the park (with coffee) to give you both something to focus on.
and
If you’re not up for getting together in person, ask to chat on the phone:

"Let's get coffee" might be your go-to first date, but if you don't know someone well (or at all), it can be a little awkward just sitting there. Try to make your first date somewhat activity-based, like mini-golfing or a walk in the park (with coffee) to give you both something to focus on.
and
If you’re not up for getting together in person, ask to chat on the phone:

points.name: What Are Conversation Topics For Talking to Someone You’re Attracted to?

steps.title: Kick it old-school: plan a first date and get to know them IRL.
steps.subtitle: Skip over the virtual get-to-know-yous and jump ahead to the  portion of the chat. You can get to know each other in person over your favorite pizza or a game of darts. (Just make sure you meet in a public place and tell your friends where you’re going!) Even if it turns out not to be a match made in heaven, who knows? You may still have a great time. And if not, you’ve got a good story to share on a future first date.
sub-points: "Let's get coffee" might be your go-to first date, but if you don't know someone well (or at all), it can be a little awkward just sitting there. Try to make your first date somewhat activity-based, like mini-golfing or a walk in the park (with coffee) to give you both something to focus on.
